awd_titl_txt: A neurophysiological examination of developmental changes and individual differences in feedback processing in children
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will illuminate neurophysiological processes responsible for children's efficient use of feedback. Children regularly encounter feedback at school and home as they learn new information or acquire new skills. Young learners must extract information from feedback, ignoring irrelevant, false, or misleading feedback, and using helpful feedback to adjust behavior and modify learning strategies. The ability to use feedback efficiently is an element of active, self-regulated learning that is critical to academic success. Understanding such learning in children requires studying how the quality of feedback processing in the brain changes with age through the early school years. By examining how individual cognitive differences affect the development of feedback processing, this project will enable development of effective evidence-based teaching approaches and computer-based learning programs that are tailored for children of different ages and with diverse cognitive profiles. The project will also lead to advances in treatments for children with developmental language disorders whose therapy relies on feedback provision. A broadly representative sample of children will participate in this research, and the study results will be shared with educators via education events held at schools serving low income and underrepresented students.

Feedback processing will be examined in eight- and ten-year-old children who will be followed over three years. In each yearly visit, children will learn new information using corrective feedback while their EEG is recorded. EEG activity will be analyzed to longitudinally investigate changes in children's ability to learn from feedback. The results will improve understanding of how feedback impacts learning, and how this impact changes with age. Working memory measures will also be collected each year and examined in relation to changes in feedback-based learning. The project involves a detailed evaluation of the maturation of feedback processing between 8 and 13 years of age, a period that marks significant developmental changes in self-regulated learning. To increase the representativeness of the participants in the project, transportation will be arranged for interested families with limited mobility.

por.por_cntn:
School-age children are expected to learn from performance feedback; to repeat behaviors that are reinforced (i.e., behaviors that are followed by positive feedback), and to change behaviors that lead to unfavorable outcomes or are followed by negative feedback. However, the ability to process performance feedback is considered a developing skill and it is unclear to what extent school-age children benefit from positive and negative feedback during their learning. 

The results of the project offer new knowledge on developmental changes in the ability to use positive and negative feedback to facilitate learning and on the relationship between working memory and feedback processing in children. The project evaluated the likelihood of children to repeat a behavior following positive feedback (referred to as stay) and to change a behavior following negative feedback (referred to as switch) in a learning task. The stay measure can indicate how well children are using positive feedback, and the switch measure can indicate how well children are using negative feedback. The results showed that the ability to learn from negative feedback measured by the rate of switching is limited among school-age children (8-13 years of age) and is developing over time. In fact, our data indicated that switching at the age of 8 was at chance level, meaning that after negative feedback, children were as likely to repeat their behavior as they were to change it. The switch behavior increased gradually to about 65% at the age of 12-13 years. These findings provide evidence that children, especially at the low end of this age group, are not using negative performance feedback effectively to facilitate their learning. 

Additional support for the limited role of negative performance feedback in facilitating learning among school-age children comes from the electrophysiological data collected as children performed the experimental tasks. These data were measured in relation to the provision of feedback and captured the brain response to positive and negative feedback. While there was a clear brain response to negative feedback, it was not related to the adjustment of behavior (i.e., switch), meaning that the detection of an unfavorable outcome was not translated into an action to improve future outcomes. Brain responses to positive feedback, on the other hand, were related to the learners' behaviors, such that a stronger response to positive feedback was associated with a higher likelihood of repeating a correct behavior. These findings strengthen the contention that positive feedback plays an important role in learning among children. 

Working memory, or the ability to hold information for a brief period while performing mental operations on that information, was found to be important for effective feedback processing in young children (around 8-9 years of age). Better working memory was found to be associated with more stay and switch behaviors and with stronger brain responses to negative feedback. Our data suggest that children become less reliant on working memory for feedback processing as they get older.

Finally, the project confirmed the hypothesis that self-monitoring, or the ability to detect errors in one's own performance improves with age and that reliance on external feedback decreases with age. These findings fit well with the theory and previous evidence that executive functions such as self-monitoring develop during childhood. 

 

The project engaged a diverse group of students in research. This group included undergraduate interns and graduate students from different disciplines (e.g., communication sciences and disorder, biology, cognitive neuroscience, engineering) and institutes. Some of the students had no previous research experience. Students received training in the collection and analysis of behavioral and electrophysiological data and participated in lab meetings, brown bags, and seminars. They developed research projects and presented results at local and national conferences.
